content: Extension of availability of SCHIP allotments for fiscal years 1998 through 2001. Extension of availability of SCHIP allotments for fiscal years 1998 through 2001 includes retaining and redistributing allotments for fiscal years 1998 and 1999, amending sections of the Social Security Act, and extending retention of a portion of the fiscal year 2000 allotment. The amendment allows states to retain and redistribute unexpended SCHIP allotments for fiscal years 1998 through 2000, extending availability for expenditure until the end of fiscal year 2004. The amendment modifies the SCHIP allotments for fiscal years 1998 through 2000, allowing states to retain and redistribute unexpended funds until the end of fiscal year 2004. The amendment adjusts SCHIP allotments for fiscal years 1998-2000, allowing states to keep and reallocate unspent funds until the end of fiscal year 2004. Additionally, it specifies the calculation of amounts for redistributions in fiscal year 2000 under subparagraph (A)(i)(III). The amendment modifies SCHIP allotments for fiscal years 1998-2000, extending the deadline for states to reallocate unused funds until 2004. Qualifying states can use SCHIP funds for Medicaid expenditures. Qualifying states can elect to use up to 20 percent of their allotment under section 2104 for fiscal years 1998-2001 for payments under title XIX instead of for expenditures under this title. If a state elects this option, the Secretary will pay the state an additional amount each quarter equal to what would have been paid under title XIX for certain expenditures. Expenditures described in clause (ii) involve medical assistance for individuals under age 19 with family income exceeding 150 percent of the poverty line. This does not impact the budget neutrality determination for waivers. A qualifying State can use funds for medical assistance under a waiver without affecting budget neutrality determinations. A qualifying State is defined as having an income eligibility standard of at least 185 percent of the poverty line for certain categories of children. The waiver under title XIX implemented in 1995 has an income eligibility standard of at least 185 percent of the poverty line for children. This does not modify the requirements for States implementing State child health plans. SEC. 2. TECHNICAL CORRECTION. Temporary Increase of the Medicaid FMAP: States eligible for FMAP increase or cap amount increase if eligibility under State plan is not more restrictive than on September 2, 2003. State can reinstate eligibility if previously restricted. States that have restricted eligibility under their State plan for Medicaid are eligible for an increase in FMAP or cap amount if they reinstate eligibility that is no more restrictive than on September 2, 2003. The amendment takes effect retroactively as if included in the Jobs and Growth Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2003.
